samples raining down from space would have no competition, given a 
hospitable environment, the transplants (microscopic flora/fauna) would 
quickly fill all biologic niches available.

one fairly reasonable explanation (unlike the absurd and preposterous 
concepts of the writer(s) and director of Prometheus), could possibly be 
caused by circumstances in snowball earth theory. this is whereby an ice 
age cycle completes to the extent that all the earth's surface is frozen, 
including the oceans which are frozen solid to a depth of anywhere from 1 
kilometer to 1 mile. life on earth, for all intents and purposes would be 
no more and after the ice age had passed the world would be a friendly 
environment for whatever organisms may make it intact to the surface.

evidence seems to indicate this snowball earth calamity may have happened 
as many as seven times in earth's history. considering the age of 'our' 
planet, the length of time the world has been viable to support life (after 
the geologic 'primordial' era had ended), this would leave approximately 
1/2 billion years for life cycles to occur. a sobering thought considering 
current life on our world has only been in existence only slightly less 
than that amount of time.

A lot of what you said is wrong but seeing how certain you are you may not 
be able to see that. Darwin said that if his theory of evolution is correct 
the fossil record would prove it, which it has not... Even with 
humans/ancestors they find many separate species but not a slow gradual 
change over time from one to the other, the fossil record supports the idea 
of huge change very quickly (meaning that whether you look at a modern 
elephant or 1 from 1.8 million years ago they are virtually the same, no 
change over time, no random mutation but the jump from mammoth to elephant 
happened in the blink of an eye with no fossils of a half elephant half 
mammoth). It is called punctuated equilibrium:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punctuated_equilibrium

To support that idea think about the marine iguana found ONLY on the 
Galapagos islands, they eat seaweed and snort the salt (from saltwater) out 
of their noses. They are black to warm them up faster after going into the 
cold ocean. Those are all adaptions from the regular iguana. Logic would 
dictate that iguanas found themselves on an island (science theorizes they 
got there by "rafting" ie. riding on a log) with no food sources and facing 
starvation they learned to dive for seaweed, perhaps they did so after 
eating all the seaweed that washes ashore. Since they are only on the 
Galapagos islands it means they adapted after they arrived and the 
adaptations are to fit their new environment, not random and likely did not 
occur over millions of years since a mere 15,000 years ago the earth was in 
a glacial period which they would not be able to survive on the 
island (just el Nino conditions kill off a lot of marine iguanas, they cant 
handle the cold) and ocean levels were so much lower they could have walked 
to south America.

For a couple million years Earth has been in an ice age, like clockwork 
there is a cycle. Earth spends 90,000 years in a glacial period (what 
layman call an ice age), then 10,000 in an interglacial period (FYI we are 
about 12,000 years into this interglacial so we are due for a new glacial) 
before the ice age Earth had no ice for most of Earths existence. So when 
you said "Some animals evolved to suit a certain part of the world/climate 
and couldn't survive in a different one" it is pretty much 100% backwards. 
The quickest animal to adapt to rapid climate changes is the survivor, 
obviously many would migrate but there is no escaping the changes. Events 
like glacial periods are the drivers of evolution.

You statement that "if organisms had totally different biological 
constructs we wouldn't be able to eat the organisms/plants for food". Is 
hilariously ignorant. Ignoring the fact that your attempt to sound 
scientific shows you know nothing of the words you use, namely, the fact 
that plants *are* organisms, we can just move on to show how hilariously 
stupid this claim is. DNA is a chain of nucleic acid. When scientists say 
we share our DNA, they mean just that, we share a chain of nucleic acid. 
What is Nucleic Acid?

Nucleic Acid is a chain of molecules called nucleotides. DNA consists of 
four nucleotides, Adenine (A), Cytosine (C), Guanine (G), and Thymine (T). 
So is the fact that all animals only have these four nucleotides what 
scientists mean when they say we share our DNA? No.

Shared DNA means sharing the same sequence. Let's say, hypothetically, that 
there is a single gene that makes our eye colour. Let's say this gene is 
nine base pairs. What does this mean? It means it is nine nucleotides long 
in a chain. The sequence AAGCATGCG may cause brown eyes, and AACCATGCG may 
cause blue. Note that only one nucleotide varies, this is called a Single 
Nucleotide Polymorphism, SNP. SNPs are what cause variations in traits, 
called alleles. So the allele for brown eyes may be the same in a person 
and in a chimp, but differ from a person with blue eyes. In this example, 
the brown eyed human and the chimp would have identical DNA (in this given 
gene), and the blue eyed person would have 8/9 identical DNA (in this 
gene). An organism that has no eyes would have 0/9 of these. 

So what is meant by saying we share our DNA? It means the chain of 
molecules is the same, identical. The variations are in the pattern, not 
the type of nucleic acid. So yes, it is 100% possible for an organism to 
have zero similarity, and still be able to be food. 

This is even more demonstrably so when we study the basics of biochemistry. 
Food is taken in from organisms, and broken down via enzymes (proteins) 
that break them down into their basic molecules (starches are chains of 
sugars, which our body breaks down into those simple sugars). The proteins 
we take in are chains of amino acids that are rearranged by our metabolic 
systems. So, it is theoretically possible (although it requires greater 
understanding yet than we currently have in order to be successful, and 
even more to become affordable), to synthetically generate chemicals that 
we can then take in for food (and on a basic level this is what we do with 
vitamins and supplements). 

Take, for example, photosynthesis in a plant. CO2 and H20 are taken in with 
sunlight. The sunlight radiation acts as a catalyst to strip the electrons 
off the molecules, effectively breaking them down into atoms (Carbon, 
Hydrogen and Oxygen). The process then adds the electron back, forming 
these atoms into new a new molecule made from these atoms, glucose. Why did 
I choose this example? Because, for one, it demonstrates that food is 
derived through chemical reactions, not just through some metaphysical life 
force, and two, it is accomplished 100% without any life, living chemicals, 
or DNA/RNA, or other similarity in other life.

I have an experiment for you, or are you afraid to put your ideas to the 
test? Grab some marbles, of two colours. Place 10, say blue, in a jar, and 
10, say white, in the same jar. *Randomly* draw a marble, and place one of 
the same colour into a second jar. Return the marble to the first jar. 
Repeat this *random* draw, until you have 20 marbles in the second jar. Do 
you have 10 of each again? Why or why not? Repeat this process until you 
have only one colour left...and you will. What occurred here?

In mathematics, this is called Sampling Error. It is caused by the fact 
that taking a sample of any population (or group of sets) will not always 
result in accurate representations , due to *random selection*. This means, 
like in the marble experiment, that if we take a sample of these marbles, 
we will get a *random* representation with limited accuracy (the larger the 
sample, the less error, hence the term sampling error).

Now ask yourself, why would this basic mathematical fact not occur in 
nature? 

Human beings, as an example, are diploid celled organisms. Ploidy means the 
number of sets of chromosomes. That means that our cells have two (di) 
copies of our chromosomes; one from our mother, and one from our father. In 
reproduction, our germ line cells (sperm in men, eggs in women) are haploid 
copies, meaning they have one set of chromosomes. If the replication of 
these chromosomes is rather constant, then it means that our sperm cells 
will have rather equal, albeit random, copies of ours. If they are randomly 
selected in our germ line, then the principles of sampling error 
mathematically *must* occur. If that were the case, then we would see the 
exact same results as the marbles. This is but one mechanism for evolution, 
and it is called *Genetic Drift*.

In fact, the marble experiment is used as an analogy to show genetic drift. 
If we consider the marble to be an allele of one gene we are looking at 
(allele meaning the variation of it, ei green eyes vs blue eyes), and we 
randomly draw these marbles, then shifts will occur in the set numbers of 
these alleles. Given enough generations, or jars, we will eventually see 
one of the two completely removed, thus a genetic trait will become *fixed* 
in a population. This means changes necessarily *must* occur in the 
populations, and that random variations will result in pattern.

If we do this experiment with say, three marble colours, and two separate 
experiments, do you think both will end up with the same colour? Give it a 
shot and see. If not, then that means that traits will vary from 
populations. Some populations (such as Europeans) may have different 
coloured eyes than others, as a result of this. These minor variations, 
over time, compound with others, to form rather large variations. Add in 
additional selective pressure, like sexual selection, and natural 
selection, and the rate of change will increase with direct proportion to 
the amount of pressure.
